Wechsler\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\">Department of Physics, Stanford University, 382 Via Pueblo Mall, Stanford, CA 94305, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=R+Wechsler\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n                            </span>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </div>\r\n\r\n                            <div class=\"al-author-name <div content-id=\"afn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Packard Fellow. This paper includes data gathered with the 6.5-m Magellan Telescopes located at Las Campanas Observatory, Chile.</p></div></span></div> \n    </div>\n                                </div>\r\n                                <a class=\"js-linked-footnotes\" href=\"javascript:;\">Author Notes</a>\r\n                            </div>\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div class=\"ww-citation-primary\"><em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 479, Issue 4, October 2018, Pages 4345\u20134354, <a href='https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty1419'>https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty1419</a></div>\r\n        </div>\r\n        <div class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>A Agnello, H Lin, N Kuropatkin, E Buckley-Geer, T Anguita, P L Schechter, T Morishita, V Motta, K Rojas, T Treu, A Amara, M W Auger, F Courbin, C D Fassnacht, J Frieman, A More, P J Marshall, R G McMahon, G Meylan, S H Suyu, K Glazebrook, N Morgan, B Nord, T M C Abbott, F B Abdalla, J Annis, K Bechtol, A Benoit-L\u00e9vy, E Bertin, R A Bernstein, D Brooks, D L Burke, A Carnero Rosell, J Carretero, C E Cunha, C B D\u2019Andrea, L N da\u00a0Costa, S Desai, A Drlica-Wagner, T F Eifler, B Flaugher, J Garc\u00eda-Bellido, E Gaztanaga, D W Gerdes, D Gruen, R A Gruendl, J Gschwend, G Gutierrez, K Honscheid, D J James, K Kuehn, O Lahav, M Lima, M A G Maia, M March, F Menanteau, R Miquel, R L C Ogando, A A Plazas, E Sanchez, V Scarpine, R Schindler, M Schubnell, I Sevilla-Noarbe, M Smith, M Soares-Santos, F Sobreira, E Suchyta, M E C Swanson, G Tarle, D Tucker, R Wechsler,  DES meets Gaia: discovery of strongly lensed quasars from a multiplet                          <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933383 id=\"118933383\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery, spectroscopic confirmation, and first lens models of the first, strongly lensed quasars from a combined search in WISE and Gaia-DR1 over the DES footprint. Their Einstein radii span a range between \u22482.0 arcsec and \u22480.4 arcsec. Two of these (WGD2038-4008, RA = 20:38:02.65, Dec. = \u221240:08:14.64; WGD2021-4115, RA = 20:21:39.45, Dec. = \u221241:15:57.11) also have confirmed deflector redshifts. The four-image lens WGD2038-4008, with source and deflector redshifts <sub><em>s</em></sub> = 0.777 \u00b1 0.001 and <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.230 \u00b1 0.002, respectively, has a deflector with radius <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> \u2248 3.4 arcsec, stellar mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log (M_{\\star }/M_{\\odot })=11.64^{+0.20}_{-0.43}$|\u2060</span>, and extended isophotal shape variation. Simple lens models yield Einstein radii <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> = (1.30 \u00b1 0.04) arcsec, axis ratio <em>q</em> = 0.75 \u00b1 0.1 (compatible with that of the starlight) and considerable shear-ellipticity degeneracies. The two-image lens WGD2021-4115 has <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 1.390 \u00b1 0.001 and <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.335 \u00b1 0.002, and Einstein radius <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> = (1.1 \u00b1 0.1) arcsec, but higher-resolution imaging is needed to accurately separate the deflector and faint quasar image. Analogous lens model degeneracies hold for the other six lenses (J0146-1133, J0150-4041, J0235-2433, J0245-0556, J0259-2338, and J0508-2748) shown in this paper.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: image processing&quot;\">techniques: image processing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"surveys\">surveys</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933385 id=\"118933385\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing by galaxies relies on the alignment of a (typically massive) galaxy with a more distant source. In the case of lensed quasars, this enables multiple lines of investigation, such as the deflector mass and density profile, in both luminous and dark matter (e.g. Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); a superresolved study of distant sources, thanks to magnification (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Ding et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and microlensing by individual stars in the deflector (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Hutsem\u00e9kers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); an unbiased census of dark and baryonic substructure around the deflector (Mao &amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Hsueh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); and the measurement of cosmological distances, from delays between different light curves (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). All these investigations are currently limited by sample size. Homogeneous samples of 20\u221240 quasar lenses, with a combination of ancillary data (e.g. spectroscopy, time delay monitoring, and deep- and high-resolution imaging), would enable substantial progress onall fronts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to assemble large samples of lensed quasars, wide areas of sky must be surveyed to overcome the intrinsic rarity of lenses. In the optical, this is made possible by ground-based surveys like the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (Abazajian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (hereafter DES, S\u00e1nchez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the VST-ATLAS (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and Pan-STARRS (Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Various techniques have been developed to find quasar lenses, using morphological and spectroscopic information (as in the SQLS and BQLS, Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), image cutout modelling (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), data mining on catalogue magnitudes (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Agnello 2017; Williams, Agnello &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), variability (Berghea et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and visual inspection of \u2018blue-near-red\u2019 objects (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In the radio, all-sky lens searches (such as CLASS and JVLA, King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) examined radio-loud sources that could be resolved into multiple components by higher-resolution follow-up.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search strategies depend on the quality of the data and on the specific kind of systems being sought. In fact, depending on the projected separation between multiple quasar images, and on the survey image quality and depth, quasar lenses may be catalogued as multiple sources with similar colours, or blended in one or more extended objects. The Gaia satellite mission (Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lindegren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; van Leeuwen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), with sharp image quality (FWHM \u2248 0.2 arcsec) and moderate depth (<em>G</em> = 20.7), can be combined with a near-infrared colour-based search from the WISE mission (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to select quasar lenses as quasar-like objects that are resolved into multiple images. The method has been detailed elsewhere (Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); here we illustrate its application to the DES year-3 footprint (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we report the discovery of eight previously unknown lensed quasars, from the joint use of WISE colour selection, Gaia multiplet detection, and DES image inspection. Of these, two (WGD2038-4008, RA = 20:38:02.65, Dec. = \u201340:08:14.64; WGD2021-4115, RA = 20:21:39.45, Dec. = \u201341:15:57.11) were followed up in 2018 August and have secured deflector redshifts. Another six (WGD0146-1133, WGD0150-4041, WGD0235-2433, WGD0245-0556, WGD0259-2338, and WGD0508-2748; see Tables<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) were confirmed in subsequent STRIDES-2017 campaigns. The same search, besides recovering known lenses, has yielded a list of potential doubles, as well as possible Galactic streams and substructure among the contaminants. Throughout this paper, we adopt the following nomenclature: <em>objects</em> denotes everything preselected via colour cuts; <em>targets</em> are objects that have been skimmed with additional techniques (a multiplet search, in this case); and <em>candidates</em> are targets that survive pixel-by-pixel examination, such as image cutout modelling or visual inspection. When a WISE source corresponds to multiple DES or Gaia <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries, the one closest to the WISE position is denoted as <em>primary</em> and the remaining ones as <em>secondary</em>. Following previous work, DES <em>grizY</em> magnitudes are given in the AB system and WISE magnitudes are in the Vega system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe our WISE\u2013Gaia\u2013DES search, the discovery of WGD2038-4008 and WGD2021-4115 and other candidates, and spectroscopic confirmation; multicomponent fits to the cutouts and gravitational lens models in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we discuss the results and future prospects of this method. The paper is briefly summarized in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933391 id=\"118933391\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 THE WISE\u2013GAIA\u2013DES SEARCH AND DISCOVERY OF LENSED QUASARS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple data-mining techniques have been applied to the search of lensed quasars in the DES, over the last 2\u00a0yr. Some objects were flagged independently within different searches (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The eight lenses in this paper (see Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) were discovered using a novel search combining WISE, Gaia and DES. All have confirmed source redshifts and two (shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) also have deflector redshifts measured.</p>                        <a id=\"118933393\" scrollto-destination=\"118933393\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=jthlgc~lk3TRmO6s~r4Fge2XuCXG1QTeM9C1QgJCpEDUMgNMiLVHqgKkCFOWrPxxML58XENzdjyTDJDlDKX13U73PfQxqL9dAAGGmDaNJ0gRCOpDfRfYxPcawKg045VC8-h4NawMhaoZ4QBSZAYpKdFmCdjCxRgN6Ick90IfeVRT9o9eonrU3kFbhI0ujpNjqHwofipdZctjzVd7ujnuLTsdb2fi26l7intblGiEdQnSfbF4Dpe5snXKqxQWNvF7NpKoDk0cq0Jhusib3vMOocGWhqXs601~fhUvvM2VtHl1P2Bm5kSHNWoPtO9SvatdwmbQlzXmX6bgyuNWZ4cM6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2038-4008. Top: 45.3 arcsec \u00d7 45.3 arcsec (172\u00a0px \u00d7 172\u00a0px) grizY cutouts, showing the dominant \u2018halo\u2019 component of the deflector and a nearby bright star used to fit for the PSF; bullets mark the locations of the objects considered in the cutout modelling, including three sources marked as S1, S2, S3. Bottom: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) grizY cutouts and colour composites, after subtracting the main \u2018halo\u2019 profile of the deflector; a flattened bulge, approximately as bright as the faintest quasar image, is visible in the gri cutouts. Images A, B, D, and C are marked following the expected ordering in arrival times; the lens galaxy G is in the centre. The central pixel artefact results from S\u00e9rsic-profile subtraction, and is not used in fitting the cutouts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933393/sty1419fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933393\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=1505KyUogJMwD8AyaDJgjHyoFlt92WIaLIrBBVagGl6mnbHlkbQV3bnD5fNMDYAFilysKnfweu88zPlMbcSV92QkFPBxjNzG9gyy0-Uqrgei58mLrtIvVwhQ1oEeoi~W68sX9FeLtfXzfYlsbzA8KCRGlzx3qWujOVSb8X4x2XlBfZon04vlnUBMUCOijzWh8wYDWErSVebhFNcxc8V-8Qi41wdeK5dYYUBhEmyqHqTvUJiu7bAI29uqcN7kx~b02OuNqxwNXUqrBTdjFT8wj2DR5vU910cZxsBAQA0bUgQEH8MdVtoW8ZRreDMlDTAISOXFRGZAFWGN3LWFBmfCDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933393&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2038-4008. <em>Top:</em> 45.3 arcsec \u00d7 45.3 arcsec (172\u00a0px \u00d7 172\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts, showing the dominant \u2018halo\u2019 component of the deflector and a nearby bright star used to fit for the PSF; bullets mark the locations of the objects considered in the cutout modelling, including three sources marked as S1, S2, S3. <em>Bottom:</em> 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts and colour composites, after subtracting the main \u2018halo\u2019 profile of the deflector; a flattened bulge, approximately as bright as the faintest quasar image, is visible in the <em>gri</em> cutouts. The central pixel artefact results from S\u00e9rsic-profile subtraction, and is not used in fitting the cutouts.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=jthlgc~lk3TRmO6s~r4Fge2XuCXG1QTeM9C1QgJCpEDUMgNMiLVHqgKkCFOWrPxxML58XENzdjyTDJDlDKX13U73PfQxqL9dAAGGmDaNJ0gRCOpDfRfYxPcawKg045VC8-h4NawMhaoZ4QBSZAYpKdFmCdjCxRgN6Ick90IfeVRT9o9eonrU3kFbhI0ujpNjqHwofipdZctjzVd7ujnuLTsdb2fi26l7intblGiEdQnSfbF4Dpe5snXKqxQWNvF7NpKoDk0cq0Jhusib3vMOocGWhqXs601~fhUvvM2VtHl1P2Bm5kSHNWoPtO9SvatdwmbQlzXmX6bgyuNWZ4cM6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2038-4008. Images A, B, D, and C are marked following the expected ordering in arrival times; the lens galaxy G is in the centre. The central pixel artefact results from S\u00e9rsic-profile subtraction, and is not used in fitting the cutouts.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"118933394\" scrollto-destination=\"118933394\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=o10H-71NeIVRvh8XJ8Jw5t37beURubeeDPzRBzdjU1Zbsa8F21KMVzM3cPqrb2KBiTC5b0n1hHV9~0ALUWU2RzTjNkxNKoRCp497YwWFKiK2c-BT8Vvh5qYddDf5sYTVkMNObsGEPGrL0ShJxy7CWFTd~Y5msHMlV4GwFJUnxM46pmbf86Fb~8EsWrpX7dx1~aBVQAPe3jRU~MRWdVMJZSAPRoHgX4PtxxHeILRNTlw70jBuGcCwlVFgOBqnc-NsUzM13ywi2kicOfk8Hqr853omxy4ziu3DxH4iZrGqGaO3XnzhptGPlBGhWuoFfAuf7p0QUJCu54xAfau8d3d0Cg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2021-4115: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) grizY cutouts and colour composites. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables 1 and\u00a02) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a02) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933394/sty1419fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933394\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=eDbK0sAGD3Gk14Kl7DMhbNp8epM~e1sS3rI9kcXDgEQxLN2s51-vGXotz-A7kg1pJC62xvWRuwbhQzld3CPp2z7FNURgbzphT9bbGnP8kOApfjuC0-Vqr0o0edyNzkgYHLaIKxx~JL8UUYlHYPUDxOnGvS0mcoiyObIcsb6hd778KekwNI3tsD8fC6cN762lWvAJ1bRq~iam-m8jCKNponhk-vU3bV8GUM6A8kSkBfBziEnNvKDvue28uFSWHOadiPIq1WdYRIRf-msCKYuoPCsgiYIR2EJ~8~nkp4fFZu27tmYQqHHZo3rw5fPG0HN5B6cz4SbLDXfI-SsAsTQyaA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933394&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2021-4115: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts and colour composites. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=o10H-71NeIVRvh8XJ8Jw5t37beURubeeDPzRBzdjU1Zbsa8F21KMVzM3cPqrb2KBiTC5b0n1hHV9~0ALUWU2RzTjNkxNKoRCp497YwWFKiK2c-BT8Vvh5qYddDf5sYTVkMNObsGEPGrL0ShJxy7CWFTd~Y5msHMlV4GwFJUnxM46pmbf86Fb~8EsWrpX7dx1~aBVQAPe3jRU~MRWdVMJZSAPRoHgX4PtxxHeILRNTlw70jBuGcCwlVFgOBqnc-NsUzM13ywi2kicOfk8Hqr853omxy4ziu3DxH4iZrGqGaO3XnzhptGPlBGhWuoFfAuf7p0QUJCu54xAfau8d3d0Cg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2021-4115: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) grizY cutouts and colour composites. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables 1 and\u00a02) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a02) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933394/sty1419fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933394\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=eDbK0sAGD3Gk14Kl7DMhbNp8epM~e1sS3rI9kcXDgEQxLN2s51-vGXotz-A7kg1pJC62xvWRuwbhQzld3CPp2z7FNURgbzphT9bbGnP8kOApfjuC0-Vqr0o0edyNzkgYHLaIKxx~JL8UUYlHYPUDxOnGvS0mcoiyObIcsb6hd778KekwNI3tsD8fC6cN762lWvAJ1bRq~iam-m8jCKNponhk-vU3bV8GUM6A8kSkBfBziEnNvKDvue28uFSWHOadiPIq1WdYRIRf-msCKYuoPCsgiYIR2EJ~8~nkp4fFZu27tmYQqHHZo3rw5fPG0HN5B6cz4SbLDXfI-SsAsTQyaA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933394&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2021-4115: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts and colour composites. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">General properties of this search strategy and numbers for other survey footprints are given by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); here we summarize the main steps: first, objects are selected based on their WISE colours; then, those corresponding to multiple <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries (i.e. \u2018multiplets\u2019) in Gaia-DR1 are retained as targets; finally, DES image cutouts of targets are visually inspected to identify lens candidates. A variation on this theme has been illustrated in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933396 id=\"118933396\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 WISE\u2013Gaia\u2013DES search</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The initial sample consisted of 173\u00a0048 objects, selected in a footprint slightly larger than the DES-Y3 one, satisfying<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update215118_equ1\" content-id=\"update215118_equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp;{W1-W2\\gt 0.55,\\ 2.2\\lt W2-W3\\lt 3.8,}\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{W1\\lt 17.0, W2\\lt 15.4, W3\\lt 11.6,} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\delta W1\\lt 0.25,\\ \\delta W2\\lt 0.3,\\ \\delta W3\\lt 0.35,}\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{W2-W3\\lt \\mathrm{max}[2.7;\\, 3.15+1.5(W1-W2-1.075)].}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>A cross-match with Gaia yielded 107\u00a0076 sources, of which 2656 are unique multiplets (i.e. WISE sources corresponding to more than one non-duplicate Gaia detection within 6 arcsec from the corresponding WISE position). A significant subset of these (\u22482000) lie within the DES-Y3 footprint. This target list was narrowed down to a sample of 53 candidates by simple visual inspection of their DES images. Among these are some recently discovered lenses, which had been previously identified with other techniques (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The WFI2033-4723 quad (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) was identified as well, whereas WFI2026-4536 was excluded by the WISE colour preselection. In order to prioritize follow-up, candidates can be further graded based on how closely they resemble lenses, based mostly on two criteria: (<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) the presence of two or more blue, compact sources with consistent colours across multiple bands; and (<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) the presence of a (typically red) galaxy between the putative quasar images. Acceptable \u2018new\u2019 candidates identified within this search are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</div>                        <a id=\"118933398\" scrollto-destination=\"118933398\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=jN0UYBFk-IDu2uiEvv8~mk9VgkYj5Xb0USm2FdZexf8YiEVibzctzDym1yU26BRYU7TH-WpB58HtSlQPEuTqQCaU1f-PefxtO3PirV5ZwaL4lTLyq-B~kCU50QIcKTzSTSz0lQidcybOPsDTlnjDSeCsPuN5~3vMQ3FR1jMj4LUmIjOcOFdJfRp4xwHZ89hqcpzpmburvGDjGtVodpfpcsVQc~G7hBzz5OgBc0jwHNcyLseuHeBRRyamlnrCyUZif5767kLXdP6WulUsQJ03rw6kdBSuGieI--FflYt9g3~x1eVZfKU0z4dfX-3O~gMIkD-gwPhvk~wA28pEoiVRyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES single-epoch cutouts of high-grade, multiplet-selected candidates that are not already known lenses. The last two (WGD0150-4041 and WGD0245-0556) have been found among DES multiplets, and correspond to singlets in Gaia-DR1. Three multiplets (WGD0259-2338, WGD0146-1133, and WGD0235-2433) have also been identified as WISE\u2013Gaia multiplets in the ATLAS-DR3 footprint, where they have coverage in just two bands.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933398/sty1419fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=bLdB4hCsOVexdsAoY5NhjkNS-5phzGwS3UxWxq3Jyn5bm0gg26k~-mbCGDcKqgtuM6iBheA~N-xoXry-1YNvf9nwQlN-mrHQvpYW~hevtQQCRER3qm-83G76NLVrkPFGTnhx9gGcjrVzcb~CJ6wislb0hAMpSGcTrRvaMl7qfuX7dbge~W9KkOLwpTuMRbTYdQtnmojOngSjCBnXj42hYcPzYNA8cne5FDlXCVRz8SGxH0RHQDRZ0DC6gmma~Wnq6WbGoize5ifBdTNOTblVYqaKIg4i6RVpVfmENCYOJxKTKiL09l~8rDE6fGqyK-fiM6UhSCWomKa25tO8VQsc5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933398&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES single-epoch cutouts of high-grade, multiplet-selected candidates that are not already known lenses. The last two (WGD0150-4041 and WGD0245-0556) have been found among DES multiplets, and correspond to singlets in Gaia-DR1. Three multiplets (WGD0259-2338, WGD0146-1133, and WGD0235-2433) have also been identified as WISE\u2013Gaia multiplets in the ATLAS-DR3 footprint, where they have coverage in just two bands.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=jN0UYBFk-IDu2uiEvv8~mk9VgkYj5Xb0USm2FdZexf8YiEVibzctzDym1yU26BRYU7TH-WpB58HtSlQPEuTqQCaU1f-PefxtO3PirV5ZwaL4lTLyq-B~kCU50QIcKTzSTSz0lQidcybOPsDTlnjDSeCsPuN5~3vMQ3FR1jMj4LUmIjOcOFdJfRp4xwHZ89hqcpzpmburvGDjGtVodpfpcsVQc~G7hBzz5OgBc0jwHNcyLseuHeBRRyamlnrCyUZif5767kLXdP6WulUsQJ03rw6kdBSuGieI--FflYt9g3~x1eVZfKU0z4dfX-3O~gMIkD-gwPhvk~wA28pEoiVRyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES single-epoch cutouts of high-grade, multiplet-selected candidates that are not already known lenses. Three multiplets (WGD0259-2338, WGD0146-1133, and WGD0235-2433) have also been identified as WISE\u2013Gaia multiplets in the ATLAS-DR3 footprint, where they have coverage in just two bands.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933398/sty1419fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=bLdB4hCsOVexdsAoY5NhjkNS-5phzGwS3UxWxq3Jyn5bm0gg26k~-mbCGDcKqgtuM6iBheA~N-xoXry-1YNvf9nwQlN-mrHQvpYW~hevtQQCRER3qm-83G76NLVrkPFGTnhx9gGcjrVzcb~CJ6wislb0hAMpSGcTrRvaMl7qfuX7dbge~W9KkOLwpTuMRbTYdQtnmojOngSjCBnXj42hYcPzYNA8cne5FDlXCVRz8SGxH0RHQDRZ0DC6gmma~Wnq6WbGoize5ifBdTNOTblVYqaKIg4i6RVpVfmENCYOJxKTKiL09l~8rDE6fGqyK-fiM6UhSCWomKa25tO8VQsc5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933398&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES single-epoch cutouts of high-grade, multiplet-selected candidates that are not already known lenses. id=\"fn-tb1fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Asterisks mark \u2018new\u2019 lenses in this paper. The i \u2212band (wavg_mag_auto) magnitude refers to the primary DES match of each WISE-detected object, which is often a blend of multiple components.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The same search over the ATLAS-DR3 footprint has yielded candidates that also lie in the DES footprint.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn3\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The last two candidates have been identified among DES multiplets that correspond to Gaia singlets.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) excludes WGD2047-48 as a line-of-sight alignment of a narrow-line galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.33, with a red galaxy and a blue star.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Some of the WISE\u2013Gaia candidates had also been identified independently, with other techniques, in the STRIDES-2016 campaign (Anguita et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Treu et al.; in preparation). Source redshifts are given for systems in this paper that have been confirmed spectroscopically as lenses or near-identical quasar pairs, after this paper was submitted, as part of the STRIDES 2017 campaigns.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" d</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>311.862\u00a0059\u00a0</td><td>\u221248.029\u00a0964\u00a0</td><td>19.11\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD2139-4331\u00a0</td><td>324.988\u00a0092\u00a0</td><td>\u221243.517\u00a0187\u00a0</td><td>17.58\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD2141-4629<sup><em>d</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>325.453\u00a0535\u00a0</td><td>\u221246.496\u00a0119\u00a0</td><td>18.95\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD2144-4228\u00a0</td><td>316.183\u00a099\u00a0</td><td>\u221242.481\u00a0507\u00a0</td><td>17.73\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD2332-4934\u00a0</td><td>353.042\u00a0968\u00a0</td><td>\u221249.568\u00a0522\u00a0</td><td>18.98\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD0150-4041<sup><em>b</em>, *</sup>\u00a0</td><td>27.736\u00a0921\u00a0</td><td>\u221240.695\u00a0568\u00a0</td><td>18.66\u00a0</td><td>1.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD0245-0556<sup><em>b</em>, *</sup>\u00a0</td><td>41.356\u00a0506\u00a0</td><td>\u22125.950\u00a0145\u00a0</td><td>18.73\u00a0</td><td>1.54\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tb1fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Asterisks mark \u2018new\u2019 lenses in this paper. The i \u2212band (wavg_mag_auto) magnitude refers to the primary DES match of each WISE-detected object, which is often a blend of multiple components.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The same search over the ATLAS-DR3 footprint has yielded candidates that also lie in the DES footprint.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn3\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The last two candidates have been identified among DES multiplets that correspond to Gaia singlets.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) excludes WGD2047-48 as a line-of-sight alignment of a narrow-line galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.33, with a red galaxy and a blue star.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Some of the WISE\u2013Gaia candidates had also been identified independently, with other techniques, in the STRIDES-2016 campaign (Anguita et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Treu et al.; in preparation). Source redshifts are given for systems in this paper that have been confirmed spectroscopically as lenses or near-identical quasar pairs, after this paper was submitted, as part of the STRIDES 2017 campaigns.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933399\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some veritable multiplets may have been classified as duplicates in the Gaia-DR1, and so were not flagged by this search. A complementary search, using DES multiplets instead of Gaia-DR1, is outlined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>. It recognized some WISE\u2013Gaia multiplets, and gave at least two additional candidates (WGD0150 and WGD0245, Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, later confirmed as lenses) as WISE\u2013DES multiplets that would correspond to WISE\u2013Gaia singlets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While other lens candidates would require spectroscopic follow-up for confirmation, WGD2038-4008 stood out due to its distinctive configuration, with four blue point-source images around a luminous red galaxy. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows multiband wide-field cutouts of the system and a close-up, with our adopted naming convention for different components and nearby sources.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933402 id=\"118933402\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Spectroscopic confirmation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Both WGD2038-4008 and WGD2021-4115 were observed with long-slit spectroscopy, to secure their lens and source redshifts, as part of a campaign to obtain follow-up spectroscopy of the lens galaxy in various quasar lenses. To this aim, IMACS at the 6.5-m Walter Baade Telescope at Magellan (Las Campanas) was used, set up in \u2018long\u2019 f/4 camera mode, covering the full 4000\u201312\u00a0000-\u00c5 wavelength range. For WGD 2038-4008, the slit was simply oriented north\u2013south and centred on the lens galaxy; since WGD2021-4115 required proper spectroscopic confirmation, the slit was oriented along the two blue images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows the extracted spectra of both systems. From emission lines, the source redshifts of the quad and double are <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 0.777 \u00b1 0.001 and <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 1.390 \u00b1 0.001, respectively. Absorption features, compatible with <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.230 \u00b1 0.002 on the quad and <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.335 \u00b1 0.002 on the double, are also identified.</p> best-fit SIE models (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), with arrival-time contours (dashed) and images of circular source-plane isophotes (full lines), for WGD2038-4008 (<em>top</em>) and WGD2021-4115 (<em>bottom</em>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the high-grade candidates from this search, along with source redshifts obtained in subsequent STRIDES-2017 campaigns. Eight systems (marked by asterisks in the table) are confirmed lenses. Of these, WGD0508-2748 has \u22480.8 arcsec image separation and could be confirmed only through high-resolution imaging follow-up, which enabled the identification of the (faint) lens galaxy (Molina et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933408 id=\"118933408\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 CUTOUT MODELS AND LENS PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Simple lens properties can be obtained by modelling the DES image cutouts. In particular, from the <em>grizY</em> survey images, we obtained photometry and relative astrometry of multiple components in the two confirmed lenses, and simple lens models based on those. Lens model configurations are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933410 id=\"118933410\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 WGD2038-4008: system configuration and gravitational lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WGD2038-4008 has a quite symmetric configuration: two saddle-point images aligned along the major axis of the deflector, and the two minima on a nearly perpendicular line. These components are all blended together by the DES pipeline, but can be disentangled by modelling the DES cutouts as a superposition of four point sources and a galaxy, for which we choose a single S\u00e9rsic profile (S\u00e9rsic <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1968</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118933412 id=\"118933412\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Photometry and astrometry of WGD2038-4008</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use a nearby, bright point source (indicated as \u2018O\u2019 in Fig. 1) to directly model the point-spread function (PSF) and the slight offset among different bands. In each band, the PSF is well fit (to within 10\u2009per\u2009cent) by a superposition of three concentric Gaussians with the same axis ratios and orientations, contributing 61\u2009, 33\u2009, and 6\u2009per\u2009cent of the total flux in the core, wings, and outskirts, respectively. Residuals from PSF mismatch are due to multipolar features that are not captured by these simple models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> lists the relative positions and <em>grizY</em> magnitudes of the four images (A, B, C, and D), deflector (G) and three additional sources (S1, S2, and S3). The deflector has a compact bulge and an extended and luminous \u2018halo\u2019, which contributes most of the light and is fit by a S\u00e9rsic profile with <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> = (3.45 \u00b1 0.12) arcsec, <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.90 \u00b1 0.05, axis ratio <em>q</em> = 0.77 \u00b1 0.01 and p.a. \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> = (41.6 \u00b1 1.6) deg (E of N). Faint features in blue bands are visible, with isophotes twisting towards 30-deg east of north. Contamination by the deflector affects the position and fluxes of image D, whose uncertainties are systematics-dominated.</p>                        <a id=\"118933415\" scrollto-destination=\"118933415\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions (relative to image A) and magnitudes of the objects in the lenses, from a joint model of the DES <em>grizY</em> single-epoch images with best image quality. The first column also lists the effective radius (<em>R<sub>e</sub></em>) and S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>) of the deflector in each system. For WGD2038-4008, the PSF is fit directly to the bright star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and three nearby compact sources are included in the fit, in order to limit systematic uncertainties on positions and magnitudes. The magnitudes quoted for G are from the main halo component, whose light dominates over the compact bulge (visible in the residuals), which is roughly as bright as image D. Uncertainties on displacements and magnitudes of image D are systematically dominated, due to contamination by G. Magnitudes in square brackets (for source S2) may be significantly affected by noise and contamination by G. For the subsequent doubles (WGD2021-4115 onwards), the PSF is fit to the farthest quasar image. The cutout image quality and proximity of deflector and counterimage render the fitted positions and magnitudes significantly uncertain. WGD0508 (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is not modelled, due to its very small image separation.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933415\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions (relative to image A) and magnitudes of the objects in the lenses, from a joint model of the DES <em>grizY</em> single-epoch images with best image quality. The first column also lists the effective radius (<em>R<sub>e</sub></em>) and S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>) of the deflector in each system. For WGD2038-4008, the PSF is fit directly to the bright star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and three nearby compact sources are included in the fit, in order to limit systematic uncertainties on positions and magnitudes. The magnitudes quoted for G are from the main halo component, whose light dominates over the compact bulge (visible in the residuals), which is roughly as bright as image D. Uncertainties on displacements and magnitudes of image D are systematically dominated, due to contamination by G. Magnitudes in square brackets (for source S2) may be significantly affected by noise and contamination by G. For the subsequent doubles (WGD2021-4115 onwards), the PSF is fit to the farthest quasar image. The cutout image quality and proximity of deflector and counterimage render the fitted positions and magnitudes significantly uncertain. WGD0508 (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is not modelled, due to its very small image separation.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n 0.07\u00a0</td><td>19.00 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>19.98 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0259-2338\u00a0</td><td>A\u00a0</td><td>0.00 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.00 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>20.07 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>19.44 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>19.73 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>18.57 \u00b1 0.16\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>R<sub>e</sub></em> = (1.33 \u00b1 0.16) arcsec\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>2.95 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.44 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>20.79 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>20.42 \u00b1 0.13\u00a0</td><td>20.09 \u00b1 0.16\u00a0</td><td>20.08 \u00b1 0.32\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>n</em> = 1.62 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td><td>G\u00a0</td><td>2.24 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>0.22 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>20.54 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>19.47 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>18.78 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>18.42 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933415\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118933416 id=\"118933416\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 Properties of the deflector galaxy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From the magnitudes of G as measured from the cutouts, we can infer its stellar mass. To this aim, we use the <span class=\"small-caps\">Fast</span> code (Kriek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), with an exponentially declining star-formation history and a Salpeter stellar IMF. We adopt the nominal magnitude uncertainties (\u03b4m = 0.016) from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, obtaining <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}(M_{\\star }/M_{\\odot })=11.40^{+0.01}_{-0.08}.$|</span> The highly skewed confidence intervals for <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> are a consequence of the small (statistical) uncertainties on the measured magnitudes and, consequently, of the steepness of the 4000-\u00c5 break. With current, broad-band data, different stellar templates are indistinguishable.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Simple lens models can be fit using the measured image positions as constraints. We do not consider flux ratio constraints, as they can be easily affected by differential reddening, microlensing, and time delays (e.g. Yonehara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>). We adopt a singular isothermal ellipsoid for the deflector, with deflections <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update215118_update215118_equ2\" content-id=\"update215118_update215118_equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\alpha _{X}\\ =\\ -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} \\arctan \\left(\\frac{X\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{\\sqrt{q^{2}X^{2}+Y^{2}}}\\right)\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\alpha _{Y}\\ =\\ -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} {\\rm arctanh} \\left(\\frac{Y\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{\\sqrt{q^{2}X^{2}+Y^{2}}}\\right)\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>in a system aligned along the principal axes (<em>X, Y</em>) of G. Here, the deflector is described solely by its lens strength <em>b</em> and axis ratio <em>q</em>, besides its position angle \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub>. We add an external shear component with uniform prior on the amplitude within 0.0 &lt; <em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em> &lt; 0.14 and uniform prior of the shear angle 0.0 &lt; \u03d5<sub><em>s</em></sub> &lt; \u03c0, and explore three different choices for the deflector shape parameters: (a) priors on <em>q</em> and \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> centred on those from cutout modelling, with larger adopted uncertainties of 0.1 and 10\u00a0deg, respectively; (b) \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> fixed to its value from cutout models, and <em>q</em> free to vary; and (c) uniform priors on <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub>. In all models, the Einstein radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm E}=b/\\sqrt{q}$|</span> has a uniform prior between 1.0 and 3.0 arcsec.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the lens model results. The Einstein radius is quite robust against the adopted priors, and approximately half the A-B image separation. The lens position angle is always close to those observed from the cutouts, whereas a significant shear-ellipticity degeneracy is present. More accurate lens models should account for the variation in shape and position angle of the observed isophotes (e.g. by using a superposition of ellipsoidal models), and possibly incorporate observations of galaxies in the vicinity of the lens in projection, to independently assess the shear component.</p>                        <a id=\"118933420\" scrollto-destination=\"118933420\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens model parameters: Einstein radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm E}=b/\\sqrt{q},$|</span> axis ratio <em>q</em>, and p.a. \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> of the main lens; external shear angle \u03d5<sub><em>s</em></sub> and amplitude \u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>; and lens centre (\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em>, \u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em>) with respect to the galaxy centre identified in the DES cutouts. Image positions are fit with an SIE for the deflector (G) and external shear to account for possible external contributions. Different lines correspond to different priors adopted on the shape parameters <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> of G (see text).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Mod.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<em><sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg.
