(b)\u00a0</td><td>1.06 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>[1.0]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>-11.0\u00b15.0\u00a0</td><td>0.21 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.03 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.02 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Mod.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<em><sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg. E of N)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg. N of W)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J2038-4008\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (a)\u00a0</td><td>1.26 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.79 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>42.0 \u00b1 7.7\u00a0</td><td>25.0 \u00b1 7.0\u00a0</td><td>0.095 \u00b1 0.025\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.04 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.04 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (b)\u00a0</td><td>1.26 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.64 \u00b1 0.22\u00a0</td><td>42.0 \u00b1 7.0\u00a0</td><td>18.0 \u00b1 35.0\u00a0</td><td>0.07 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.06 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.05 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (c)\u00a0</td><td>1.32 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.44 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>32.2 \u00b1 5.05\u00a0</td><td>\u221275.4 \u00b1 50.3\u00a0</td><td>0.02 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.06 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.05 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2021-4115\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (a)\u00a0</td><td>1.25 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.50 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>8.0 \u00b1 4.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>0.02 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.00 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (b)\u00a0</td><td>1.06 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>[1.0]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>-11.0\u00b15.0\u00a0</td><td>0.21 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.03 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.02 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933420\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933421 id=\"118933421\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 WGD2021-4115: system configuration and gravitational lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WGD2021-4115 consists of two quasar images at either side of a round, faint, red galaxy (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We denote the farther image (with shorter arrival time) as A. Its counterimage B lies very close to the deflector galaxy. The same approach as above has been followed for WGD2021-4115, obtaining object positions and <em>grizY</em> magnitudes from the DES image cutouts and performing simple lens models. The astrometry and photometry of the three components is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. In this case, G is smaller, fainter, and very close to image B, which makes the cutout models highly degenerate. The structural parameters of G cannot be recovered reliably, and its magnitudes have significant uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From simple lens models, a high-quadrupole component (shear <em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em> = 0.20 \u00b1 0.04 or flattening <em>q</em> = 0.50 \u00b1 0.08) is needed to account for the off-centring of images A and B with respect to the lens galaxy, still producing only two quasar images due to the highly asymmetric configuration. The Einstein radius ((1.25 \u00b1 0.05) arcsec from SIE, (1.06 \u00b1 0.07) arcsec from SIS + XS) is comparable to half the A\u2013B image separation, but due to the significant quadrupole it depends appreciably on the chosen lens model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similar arguments hold in general for the remaining doubles in this sample. With current imaging data, the lens parameters have comparable uncertainties for all doubles. Lens models based on follow-up, adaptive-optics assisted imaging are beyond the scope of this paper, and will be presented elsewhere (Molina et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933425 id=\"118933425\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The combination of WISE colour selection and Gaia/DES image quality and depth has resulted in the discovery of the lensed quasar quad WGD2038-4008 and a sample of high-grade candidate doubles, seven of which have been confirmed as lenses (Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Due to different survey strategy, source-detection pipelines, and depth and image quality, Gaia can detect multiple sources that are unrecognized in DES and vice versa. Also, the current performance of the WISE\u2013Gaia multiplet search is limited by the preselection cuts in WISE and absence of colour information in Gaia-DR1. These aspects are discussed below.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933427 id=\"118933427\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 DES multiplets</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The WISE\u2013Gaia search took 173\u00a0048 input positions, but resulted in fewer (107\u00a0076) output detections. This is mostly because of the current Gaia-DR1 <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> completeness towards faint magnitudes, and pipeline-specific choices in source detection and deblending. By contrast, a WISE\u2013DES match resulted in 206\u00a0671 entries, meaning that \u224850 \u00d7 10<sup>3</sup> WISE objects correspond to multiple DES-detected sources within a search radius of 10 arcsec. This suggests that some interesting objects are missed or misclassified by Gaia but can be recovered within DES multiplets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the other hand, many WISE\u2013DES multiplets can contain very faint objects, mostly galaxies, or line-of-sight alignments of extragalactic objects with foreground stars. Foreground star contamination is already present in the WISE\u2013Gaia selection, as the distribution of multiplets is more abundant towards the Galactic disc, the Large Magellanic Cloud and in general along stellar overdensities. In a WISE\u2013DES multiplet search, <em>grizY</em> magnitudes can be used to infer which multiplets are most likely contaminants, and which ones are more promising, as one can expect a qso+star alignment to show two well-separated objects, possibly with different colours.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A simple search can then exclude multiplets with separation \u22733 arcsec and with at least one point source, or multiplets whose primary has promising quasar colours (<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 0.85) and a colour difference |\u03b4(<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>)| &gt; 0.4 between primary and secondary detected sources. The separation criterion is chosen because, at large Einstein radii, the lens galaxy should be detectable by the DESpipeline.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If this selection is effective, what remains should be almost uniformly distributed over the DES footprint. For a first assessment of the efficiency of this procedure, and account for footprint coverage, one can simply plot the distribution of different systems. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the distribution of WISE\u2013DES singlets, WISE\u2013DES multiplets that survive the above cuts in separation and colour difference, and WISE\u2013DES multiplets that should be mostly extragalactic+star alignments. Three distributions are shown, corresponding to singlets/multiplets, whose primary has 23.0 &gt; <em>i</em> &gt; 21.75, 21.75 &gt; <em>i</em> &gt; 20.5, and 20.5 &gt; <em>i</em> respectively. The magnitude separation is used to understand whether contamination is more significant towards faint objects, or in specific regions of the sky.</p>                        <a id=\"118933432\" scrollto-destination=\"118933432\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=dFYtXLimxNMEDbf~aRYz~eo6v6y7Rpx~jB5s0gM~MN~kLGruEsKi1NQjEvQNtkzPuRD8xamG664ldttdyUq2BDkEA5bWrPvnbi7TdJezIFEPfwC4hhtk9wQ9bnsPV5dLpiYmt6ZlDLukwwWsvNV1~ifOfJUk5stPL59EGVqANe3iueD~4X0YugnkiSinhJLIKtJIw~WIBGwRCkebpfZu6xi4oFiyXMRBM66Gcs3r~31lkcnzeR88UWIMSa-FHSt6lI4bO--mAE5w8jewNT8l189x6kZ5t0ACsEusu44HW3klmBvZ30LrjLuMD7LdHcbKoihi4-nK9gBm31ZAtSnD-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has i &lt; 20.5 (wavg_mag_auto); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933432/sty1419fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933432\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=UjsTBqVgtIH7hghdPERbv69-Q5DYCCxAGx7DBXUEza-TfSdbXUkXcf9W7yCENsW9g13TQZR3jw8RqhjC7M1AEYI4CSk6UgviUImBdF5DTb7GWDZdc9eHYk4Jp6F66KqXFi2e3C1sh2QWxN~oHppCojJzrhU5h1JnaUDoVO9R5o36CZB0sBjupHz7k9~WW0DPt5TSCCsDYe~GtChVXDr1OFfSpQuCRX3zszQS625M6Htqv53HagWgQe7QR2WpQIHGeMG~i1X0Ko2Mb8A4IX8Qd1ir~5BWk0Q9xtDZw~savgdB~gH4XPfRJFkM2GLSdKwg71-EJx~sWtZDBgObN9k8Xw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933432&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (<span class=\"monospace\">wavg_mag_auto</span>); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=dFYtXLimxNMEDbf~aRYz~eo6v6y7Rpx~jB5s0gM~MN~kLGruEsKi1NQjEvQNtkzPuRD8xamG664ldttdyUq2BDkEA5bWrPvnbi7TdJezIFEPfwC4hhtk9wQ9bnsPV5dLpiYmt6ZlDLukwwWsvNV1~ifOfJUk5stPL59EGVqANe3iueD~4X0YugnkiSinhJLIKtJIw~WIBGwRCkebpfZu6xi4oFiyXMRBM66Gcs3r~31lkcnzeR88UWIMSa-FHSt6lI4bO--mAE5w8jewNT8l189x6kZ5t0ACsEusu44HW3klmBvZ30LrjLuMD7LdHcbKoihi4-nK9gBm31ZAtSnD-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has i &lt; 20.5 (wavg_mag_auto); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933432/sty1419fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933432\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=UjsTBqVgtIH7hghdPERbv69-Q5DYCCxAGx7DBXUEza-TfSdbXUkXcf9W7yCENsW9g13TQZR3jw8RqhjC7M1AEYI4CSk6UgviUImBdF5DTb7GWDZdc9eHYk4Jp6F66KqXFi2e3C1sh2QWxN~oHppCojJzrhU5h1JnaUDoVO9R5o36CZB0sBjupHz7k9~WW0DPt5TSCCsDYe~GtChVXDr1OFfSpQuCRX3zszQS625M6Htqv53HagWgQe7QR2WpQIHGeMG~i1X0Ko2Mb8A4IX8Qd1ir~5BWk0Q9xtDZw~savgdB~gH4XPfRJFkM2GLSdKwg71-EJx~sWtZDBgObN9k8Xw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933432&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (<span class=\"monospace\">wavg_mag_auto</span>); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We remark that, within the search reported in this paper, these plots have mostly an illustrative purpose. A ranking based on local (over-)density was not used, since the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {O}(10^3)$|</span> targets could be quickly inspected visually, but has been developed in subsequent work on larger footprints and looser colour preselection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fourth column displays the multiplet distribution regardless of primary magnitude. The blue points in the last row show the distribution of all WISE\u2013Gaia multiplet targets from Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Among the WISE\u2013DES multiplets with acceptable configurations and colour differences, many have extended morphology,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> a secondary with <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &gt; 1, and small colour differences (|\u03b4(<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>)| &lt; 0.2, |\u03b4(<em>r</em> \u2212 <em>z</em>)| &lt; 0.2). They can be interpreted as pairs of compact narrow-line galaxies, a common contaminant in quasar lens searches without <em>u</em> \u2212band information. A na\u00efve selection may then require <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 0.85 for all sources. The resulting multiplets with primary <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 are shown by blue dots in the second row of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, and amount to 233 (respectively 179, 405) pairs with secondary <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (respectively 20.5 &lt; <em>i</em> &lt; 21.75, 21.75 &lt; <em>i</em> &lt; 23.0). These have been visually inspected, finding some WISE\u2013Gaia candidates independently and yielding at least two good candidates that corresponded to Gaia-DR1 singlets (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), WGD0150 and WGD025, subsequently confirmed spectroscopically as lenses.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933435 id=\"118933435\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Future prospects</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This search has mostly relied on a WISE\u2013Gaia preselection, with a final step of DES image inspection. The WISE colour preselection, tailored on the majority of known lenses, may nonetheless be too restrictive, as it discards some known lenses (including quads) in the remaining \u2018upper wedge\u2019 <em>W</em>2 \u2212 <em>W</em>3 &gt;\u20093.15 + 1.5(<em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 \u2212 1.075). A crude estimate, based on the number of known lenses that lie in the excluded region, suggests that a further \u224850\u2009per\u2009cent of targets (and possibly candidates) can be identified there.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While quads like WGD2038-4008 need little follow-up for confirmation, spatially resolved spectroscopy of candidate doubles is necessary. A clear example is given by WGD2047-4814 (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>): it had already been selected with a different technique (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>) in DES-Y2 and prioritized as a high-grade candidate, but it was recognized by long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) as a <em>z</em> = 0.33 narrow-line galaxy aligned with a red galaxy and a blue star (Motta, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, private communication).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A key component of this investigation was the detection of Gaia multiplets, not flagged as duplicate detections, within a 6 arcsec search radius from WISE-selected quasars. Given the Gaia scanning strategy and object-detection pipeline, some actual multiplets may have been flagged as duplicates in the Gaia-DR1 catalogue. In fact, only about\u200920\u221230\u2009per\u2009cent of known lenses are currently recognized as multiple unique sources in Gaia-DR1. Upcoming releases (aiming at 0.4 arcsec resolution) may alleviate this issue, since each object is visited multiple times and with different orientations. A complementary search, examining WISE\u2013DES multiplets, may refine the distance/colour cuts explored above (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>), adopting a population-mixture approach for pairs/multiplets of objects. This may, in fact, be possible already at the level of Gaia colours, as Gaia-DR2 is also providing \u2018blue\u2019 and \u2018red\u2019 internal magnitudes.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933439 id=\"118933439\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the first results of a new search for lensed quasars based on the combination of mid-infrared photometry from WISE, high resolution from Gaia, and multiband optical imaging from DES. This search has found already-known lenses and some new ones discovered during the STRIDES-2016/2017 campaigns,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> and it yielded \u224850 quasar lens candidates in the DES-Y3 footprint, of which 18 high-grade candidates are presented in this paper (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of these, WGD2038-4008 is a quadruply lensed quasar, not previously found with other techniques. Its deflector is a massive (log\u2009(<em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>) \u2248 11.5) and low-redshift (<em>z<sub>l</sub></em> \u2248 0.23) luminous red galaxy, with a compact bulge, a bright halo contributing most of the light, and indication of isophotal shape variations at large distances. Simple lens models can be well fit to its image configuration. The deflector shape parameters obtained from lensing are in general agreement with those observed from the DES <em>grizY</em> cutouts, but there are significant quadrupole degeneracies that will need follow-up imaging to be resolved. The Einstein radius is quite robustly constrained at (1.30 \u00b1 0.04) arcsec, whereas the main \u2018halo\u2019 component of the deflector has half-light radius <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> = (3.45 \u00b1 0.12) arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The double WGD2021-4115 has been followed up spectroscopically and confirmed as a lens. Its configuration has an arrival-time minimum (image A) well separated from the blend of arrival-time saddle point (image B) and deflector. A high-quadrupole component is expected from our first lens models, and the Einstein radius (1.3 arcsec &gt; \u03b8<sub>E</sub> &gt; 1.0 arcsec) can vary appreciably because of this.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The WISE\u2013Gaia\u2013DES multiplet search can be further developed in multiple ways. Multiband information from DES can be used to augment the multiplet recognition, by pruning different classes of contaminants. The WISE colour preselection can be performed with looser cuts, or within a population-mixture classification to exclude the most abundant contaminant classes. Furthermore, chromatic information will be available since Gaia-DR2, and spectra of most Gaia sources will be available upon completion (2020). In fact, archival fibre spectra of WGD2038-4008 were already available from the Six-degree-field Galaxy Survey (6dFGS; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), where the object was targeted as a bright galaxy and the image quality of older imaging surveys precluded its identification as a lensed quasar.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With this work, we have demonstrated the effectiveness of the WISE\u2013Gaia lens search, discovering new lenses (among which a quadruple), that could not be found with previously developed techniques. At this stage, however, the quantification of how different search techniques are complementary is premature, as comprehensive samples with spectroscopic follow-up are needed to that purpose. Our results suggest that a significant population of lensed quasars may still be found in current surveys, enabling the collection of lens samples for studies of distant quasars (both their hosts and central engines), luminous and dark matter in galaxies over a range of redshifts, and cosmography.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933445 id=\"118933445\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper was written as part of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) collaboration, a broad external collaboration of the Dark Energy Survey, <span class=\"monospace\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://strides.astro.ucla.edu\" target=\"_blank\">http://strides.astro.ucla.edu</a></span></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">TT acknowledges support from NSF through grant AST-1450141, and from the Packard Foundation through a Packard Research Fellowship. CDF acknowledges support from the U.S. National Science Foundation through grant number AST-1312329.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the DOE and NSF (USA), MISE (Spain), STFC (UK), HEFCE (UK), NCSA (UIUC), KICP (U. Chicago), CCAPP (Ohio State), MIFPA (Texas A&amp;M), CNPQ, FAPERJ, FINEP (Brazil), MINECO (Spain), DFG (Germany), and the Collaborating Institutions in the Dark Energy Survey. C.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2016</div>, preprint (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://arxiv.org/abs/1612.05560\" target=\"_blank\">arXiv:1612.05560</a>)</p><!--citationLinks: case 3--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib9\" data-legacy-id=\"bib9\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib9\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib9\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib9\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Dalal</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">N.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Kochanek</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C. S.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2002</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">572</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">25</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1086/340303\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1086/340303</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/apj.2002.572.issue-1\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1086%2Fapj.2002.572.issue-1\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div The first column also lists the effective radius (<em>R<sub>e</sub></em>) and S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>) of the deflector in each system. For WGD2038-4008, the PSF is fit directly to the bright star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span>1, and three nearby compact sources are included in the fit, in order to limit systematic uncertainties on positions and magnitudes. The magnitudes quoted for G are from the main halo component, whose light dominates over the compact bulge (visible in the residuals), which is roughly as bright as image D. Uncertainties on displacements and magnitudes of image D are systematically dominated, due to contamination by G. Magnitudes in square brackets (for source S2) may be significantly affected by noise and contamination by G. For the subsequent doubles (WGD2021-4115 onwards), the PSF is fit to the farthest quasar image. The cutout image quality and proximity of deflector and counterimage render the fitted positions and magnitudes significantly uncertain. WGD0508 (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span>1) is not modelled, due to its very small image separation.</p></div> </div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions (relative to image A) and magnitudes of the objects in the lenses, from a joint model of the DES <em>grizY</em> single-epoch images with best image quality. The first column also lists the effective radius (<em>R<sub>e</sub></em>) and S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>) of the deflector in each system. For WGD2038-4008, the PSF is fit directly to the bright star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span>1, and three nearby compact sources are included in the fit, in order to limit systematic uncertainties on positions and magnitudes. The magnitudes quoted for G are from the main halo component, whose light dominates over the compact bulge (visible in the residuals), which is roughly as bright as image D. Uncertainties on displacements and magnitudes of image D are systematically dominated, due to contamination by G. Magnitudes in square brackets (for source S2) may be significantly affected by noise and contamination by G. For the subsequent doubles (WGD2021-4115 onwards), the PSF is fit to the farthest quasar image. The cutout image quality and proximity of deflector and counterimage render the fitted positions and magnitudes significantly uncertain. WGD0508 (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span>1) is not modelled, due to its very small image separation.</p></div> </div><div external shear angle \u03d5<sub><em>s</em></sub> and amplitude \u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>; and lens centre (\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em>, \u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em>) with respect to the galaxy centre identified in the DES cutouts. Image positions are fit with an SIE for the deflector (G) and external shear to account for possible external contributions. Different lines correspond to different priors adopted on the shape parameters <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> of G (see text).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Mod.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<em><sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg. Image positions are fit with an SIE for the deflector (G) and external shear to account for possible external contributions. id=\"fn-tb1fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Asterisks mark \u2018new\u2019 lenses in this paper. The i \u2212band (wavg_mag_auto) magnitude refers to the primary DES match of each WISE-detected object, which is often a blend of multiple components.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The same search over the ATLAS-DR3 footprint has yielded candidates that also lie in the DES footprint.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn3\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The last two candidates have been identified among DES multiplets that correspond to Gaia singlets.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) excludes WGD2047-48 as a line-of-sight alignment of a narrow-line galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.33, with a red galaxy and a blue star.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Some of the WISE\u2013Gaia candidates had also been identified independently, with other techniques, in the STRIDES-2016 campaign (Anguita et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span>2008; Treu et al.; in preparation). Source redshifts are given for systems in this paper that have been confirmed spectroscopically as lenses or near-identical quasar pairs, after this paper was submitted, as part of the STRIDES 2017 campaigns.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div candidates that are not already known lenses.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n id=\"fn-tb1fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Asterisks mark \u2018new\u2019 lenses in this paper. The i \u2212band (wavg_mag_auto) magnitude refers to the primary DES match of each WISE-detected object, which is often a blend of multiple components.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The same search over the ATLAS-DR3 footprint has yielded candidates that also lie in the DES footprint.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn3\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The last two candidates have been identified among DES multiplets that correspond to Gaia singlets.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) excludes WGD2047-48 as a line-of-sight alignment of a narrow-line galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.33, with a red galaxy and a blue star.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Some of the WISE\u2013Gaia candidates had also been identified independently, with other techniques, in the STRIDES-2016 campaign (Anguita et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span>2008; Treu et al.; in preparation). Source redshifts are given for systems in this paper that have been confirmed spectroscopically as lenses or near-identical quasar pairs, after this paper was submitted, as part of the STRIDES 2017 campaigns.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\"             }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"article\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"mnras/article/479/4/4345/5032807\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>A Agnello, H Lin, N Kuropatkin, E Buckley-Geer, T Anguita, P L Schechter, T Morishita, V Motta, K Rojas, T Treu, A Amara, M W Auger, F Courbin, C D Fassnacht, J Frieman, A More, P J Marshall, R G McMahon, G Meylan, S H Suyu, K Glazebrook, N Morgan, B Nord, T M C Abbott, F B Abdalla, J Annis, K Bechtol, A Benoit-L\u00e9vy, E Bertin, R A Bernstein, D Brooks, D L Burke, A Carnero Rosell, J Carretero, C E Cunha, C B D\u2019Andrea, L N da\u00a0Costa, S Desai, A Drlica-Wagner, T F Eifler, B Flaugher, J Garc\u00eda-Bellido, E Gaztanaga, D W Gerdes, D Gruen, R A Gruendl, J Gschwend, G Gutierrez, K Honscheid, D J James, K Kuehn, O Lahav, M Lima, M A G Maia, M March, F Menanteau, R Miquel, R L C Ogando, A A Plazas, E Sanchez, V Scarpine, R Schindler, M Schubnell, I Sevilla-Noarbe, M Smith, M Soares-Santos, F Sobreira, E Suchyta, M E C Swanson, G Tarle, D Tucker, R Wechsler,  DES meets Gaia: discovery of strongly lensed quasars from a multiplet search, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 479, Issue 4, October 2018, Pages 4345\u20134354, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty1419\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty1419</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form action=\"/Citation/Download\" method=\"get\" id=\"citationModal\">\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"resourceId\" value=\"5032807\" />\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" </div>\n\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-tools\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a              <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul     <li><a class=\"addthis_button_compact\"><span>More</span></a></li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                    <div class=\"toolbar-search\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SitePageHeader widget-instance-OUP_ArticleToolbarSearchBox\">\n        \r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"dropdown-panel-wrap\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-search-dropdown\">\r\n        <div class=\"mobile-search-inner-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                    <div id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchTerm\">\r\n\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MobileMicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search-icon mobile-search-submit class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci           <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f479%2f4%2f4345%2f5032807\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n       <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933383 id=\"118933383\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery, spectroscopic confirmation, and first lens models of the first, strongly lensed quasars from a combined search in WISE and Gaia-DR1 over the DES footprint. Their Einstein radii span a range between \u22482.0 arcsec and \u22480.4 arcsec. Two of these (WGD2038-4008, RA = 20:38:02.65, Dec. = \u221240:08:14.64; WGD2021-4115, RA = 20:21:39.45, Dec. = \u221241:15:57.11) also have confirmed deflector redshifts. The four-image lens WGD2038-4008, with source and deflector redshifts <sub><em>s</em></sub> = 0.777 \u00b1 0.001 and <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.230 \u00b1 0.002, respectively, has a deflector with radius <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> \u2248 3.4 arcsec, stellar mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log (M_{\\star }/M_{\\odot })=11.64^{+0.20}_{-0.43}$|\u2060</span>, and extended isophotal shape variation. Simple lens models yield Einstein radii <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> = (1.30 \u00b1 0.04) arcsec, axis ratio <em>q</em> = 0.75 \u00b1 0.1 (compatible with that of the starlight) and considerable shear-ellipticity degeneracies. The two-image lens WGD2021-4115 has <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 1.390 \u00b1 0.001 and <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.335 \u00b1 0.002, and Einstein radius <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> = (1.1 \u00b1 0.1) arcsec, but higher-resolution imaging is needed to accurately separate the deflector and faint quasar image. Analogous lens model degeneracies hold for the other six lenses (J0146-1133, J0150-4041, J0235-2433, J0245-0556, J0259-2338, and J0508-2748) shown in this paper.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: image processing&quot;\">techniques: image processing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"surveys\">surveys</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933385 id=\"118933385\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing by galaxies relies on the alignment of a (typically massive) galaxy with a more distant source. In the case of lensed quasars, this enables multiple lines of investigation, such as the deflector mass and density profile, in both luminous and dark matter (e.g. Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); a superresolved study of distant sources, thanks to magnification (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Ding et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and microlensing by individual stars in the deflector (Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Hutsem\u00e9kers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); an unbiased census of dark and baryonic substructure around the deflector (Mao &amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Hsueh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); and the measurement of cosmological distances, from delays between different light curves (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). All these investigations are currently limited by sample size. Homogeneous samples of 20\u221240 quasar lenses, with a combination of ancillary data (e.g. spectroscopy, time delay monitoring, and deep- and high-resolution imaging), would enable substantial progress onall fronts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to assemble large samples of lensed quasars, wide areas of sky must be surveyed to overcome the intrinsic rarity of lenses. In the optical, this is made possible by ground-based surveys like the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (Abazajian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (hereafter DES, S\u00e1nchez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the VST-ATLAS (Shanks et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and Pan-STARRS (Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Various techniques have been developed to find quasar lenses, using morphological and spectroscopic information (as in the SQLS and BQLS, Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), image cutout modelling (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), data mining on catalogue magnitudes (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Agnello 2017; Williams, Agnello &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), variability (Berghea et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and visual inspection of \u2018blue-near-red\u2019 objects (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In the radio, all-sky lens searches (such as CLASS and JVLA, King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) examined radio-loud sources that could be resolved into multiple components by higher-resolution follow-up.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search strategies depend on the quality of the data and on the specific kind of systems being sought. In fact, depending on the projected separation between multiple quasar images, and on the survey image quality and depth, quasar lenses may be catalogued as multiple sources with similar colours, or blended in one or more extended objects. The Gaia satellite mission (Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lindegren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; van Leeuwen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), with sharp image quality (FWHM \u2248 0.2 arcsec) and moderate depth (<em>G</em> = 20.7), can be combined with a near-infrared colour-based search from the WISE mission (Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to select quasar lenses as quasar-like objects that are resolved into multiple images. The method has been detailed elsewhere (Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); here we illustrate its application to the DES year-3 footprint (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we report the discovery of eight previously unknown lensed quasars, from the joint use of WISE colour selection, Gaia multiplet detection, and DES image inspection. Of these, two (WGD2038-4008, RA = 20:38:02.65, Dec. = \u201340:08:14.64; WGD2021-4115, RA = 20:21:39.45, Dec. = \u201341:15:57.11) were followed up in 2018 August and have secured deflector redshifts. Another six (WGD0146-1133, WGD0150-4041, WGD0235-2433, WGD0245-0556, WGD0259-2338, and WGD0508-2748; see Tables<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) were confirmed in subsequent STRIDES-2017 campaigns. The same search, besides recovering known lenses, has yielded a list of potential doubles, as well as possible Galactic streams and substructure among the contaminants. Throughout this paper, we adopt the following nomenclature: <em>objects</em> denotes everything preselected via colour cuts; <em>targets</em> are objects that have been skimmed with additional techniques (a multiplet search, in this case); and <em>candidates</em> are targets that survive pixel-by-pixel examination, such as image cutout modelling or visual inspection. When a WISE source corresponds to multiple DES or Gaia <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries, the one closest to the WISE position is denoted as <em>primary</em> and the remaining ones as <em>secondary</em>. Following previous work, DES <em>grizY</em> magnitudes are given in the AB system and WISE magnitudes are in the Vega system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe our WISE\u2013Gaia\u2013DES search, the discovery of WGD2038-4008 and WGD2021-4115 and other candidates, and spectroscopic confirmation; multicomponent fits to the cutouts and gravitational lens models in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we discuss the results and future prospects of this method. The paper is briefly summarized in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933391 id=\"118933391\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 THE WISE\u2013GAIA\u2013DES SEARCH AND DISCOVERY OF LENSED QUASARS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple data-mining techniques have been applied to the search of lensed quasars in the DES, over the last 2\u00a0yr. Some objects were flagged independently within different searches (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The eight lenses in this paper (see Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) were discovered using a novel search combining WISE, Gaia and DES. All have confirmed source redshifts and two (shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) also have deflector redshifts measured.</p>                        <a id=\"118933393\" scrollto-destination=\"118933393\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=jthlgc~lk3TRmO6s~r4Fge2XuCXG1QTeM9C1QgJCpEDUMgNMiLVHqgKkCFOWrPxxML58XENzdjyTDJDlDKX13U73PfQxqL9dAAGGmDaNJ0gRCOpDfRfYxPcawKg045VC8-h4NawMhaoZ4QBSZAYpKdFmCdjCxRgN6Ick90IfeVRT9o9eonrU3kFbhI0ujpNjqHwofipdZctjzVd7ujnuLTsdb2fi26l7intblGiEdQnSfbF4Dpe5snXKqxQWNvF7NpKoDk0cq0Jhusib3vMOocGWhqXs601~fhUvvM2VtHl1P2Bm5kSHNWoPtO9SvatdwmbQlzXmX6bgyuNWZ4cM6A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2038-4008. Top: 45.3 arcsec \u00d7 45.3 arcsec (172\u00a0px \u00d7 172\u00a0px) grizY cutouts, showing the dominant \u2018halo\u2019 component of the deflector and a nearby bright star used to fit for the PSF; bullets mark the locations of the objects considered in the cutout modelling, including three sources marked as S1, S2, S3. Bottom: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) grizY cutouts and colour composites, after subtracting the main \u2018halo\u2019 profile of the deflector; a flattened bulge, approximately as bright as the faintest quasar image, is visible in the gri cutouts. Images A, B, D, and C are marked following the expected ordering in arrival times; the lens galaxy G is in the centre. The central pixel artefact results from S\u00e9rsic-profile subtraction, and is not used in fitting the cutouts.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933393/sty1419fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933393\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=1505KyUogJMwD8AyaDJgjHyoFlt92WIaLIrBBVagGl6mnbHlkbQV3bnD5fNMDYAFilysKnfweu88zPlMbcSV92QkFPBxjNzG9gyy0-Uqrgei58mLrtIvVwhQ1oEeoi~W68sX9FeLtfXzfYlsbzA8KCRGlzx3qWujOVSb8X4x2XlBfZon04vlnUBMUCOijzWh8wYDWErSVebhFNcxc8V-8Qi41wdeK5dYYUBhEmyqHqTvUJiu7bAI29uqcN7kx~b02OuNqxwNXUqrBTdjFT8wj2DR5vU910cZxsBAQA0bUgQEH8MdVtoW8ZRreDMlDTAISOXFRGZAFWGN3LWFBmfCDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933393&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2038-4008. <em>Top:</em> 45.3 arcsec \u00d7 45.3 arcsec (172\u00a0px \u00d7 172\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts, showing the dominant \u2018halo\u2019 component of the deflector and a nearby bright star used to fit for the PSF; bullets mark the locations of the objects considered in the cutout modelling, including three sources marked as S1, S2, S3. <em>Bottom:</em> 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts and colour composites, after subtracting the main \u2018halo\u2019 profile of the deflector; a flattened bulge, approximately as bright as the faintest quasar image, is visible in the <em>gri</em> cutouts. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables 1 and\u00a02) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a02) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933394/sty1419fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933394\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=eDbK0sAGD3Gk14Kl7DMhbNp8epM~e1sS3rI9kcXDgEQxLN2s51-vGXotz-A7kg1pJC62xvWRuwbhQzld3CPp2z7FNURgbzphT9bbGnP8kOApfjuC0-Vqr0o0edyNzkgYHLaIKxx~JL8UUYlHYPUDxOnGvS0mcoiyObIcsb6hd778KekwNI3tsD8fC6cN762lWvAJ1bRq~iam-m8jCKNponhk-vU3bV8GUM6A8kSkBfBziEnNvKDvue28uFSWHOadiPIq1WdYRIRf-msCKYuoPCsgiYIR2EJ~8~nkp4fFZu27tmYQqHHZo3rw5fPG0HN5B6cz4SbLDXfI-SsAsTQyaA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933394&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2021-4115: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) <em>grizY</em> cutouts and colour composites. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=o10H-71NeIVRvh8XJ8Jw5t37beURubeeDPzRBzdjU1Zbsa8F21KMVzM3cPqrb2KBiTC5b0n1hHV9~0ALUWU2RzTjNkxNKoRCp497YwWFKiK2c-BT8Vvh5qYddDf5sYTVkMNObsGEPGrL0ShJxy7CWFTd~Y5msHMlV4GwFJUnxM46pmbf86Fb~8EsWrpX7dx1~aBVQAPe3jRU~MRWdVMJZSAPRoHgX4PtxxHeILRNTlw70jBuGcCwlVFgOBqnc-NsUzM13ywi2kicOfk8Hqr853omxy4ziu3DxH4iZrGqGaO3XnzhptGPlBGhWuoFfAuf7p0QUJCu54xAfau8d3d0Cg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-epoch cutouts of WGD2021-4115: 7.9 arcsec \u00d7 7.9 arcsec (30\u00a0px \u00d7 30\u00a0px) grizY cutouts and colour composites. Axes intersect at image A (the farthest and with the shortest arrival time); the counterimage B is blended with the lens G. Due to image quality and B-G proximity, uncertainties on astrometry and photometry in WGD2021-4115 are systematics dominated. This holds true also for the other doubles in this paper (Tables <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) that only have confirmed source redshifts so far. The magnitudes of the components in each system (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) are obtained by modelling the single-epoch cutouts as superpositions of two (or more) point sources and a galaxy parameterized with a S\u00e9rsic profile.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">General properties of this search strategy and numbers for other survey footprints are given by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); here we summarize the main steps: first, objects are selected based on their WISE colours; then, those corresponding to multiple <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> entries (i.e. \u2018multiplets\u2019) in Gaia-DR1 are retained as targets; finally, DES image cutouts of targets are visually inspected to identify lens candidates. A variation on this theme has been illustrated in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933396 id=\"118933396\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 WISE\u2013Gaia\u2013DES search</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The initial sample consisted of 173\u00a0048 objects, selected in a footprint slightly larger than the DES-Y3 one, satisfying<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update215118_equ1\" content-id=\"update215118_equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp;{W1-W2\\gt 0.55,\\ 2.2\\lt W2-W3\\lt 3.8,}\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{W1\\lt 17.0, W2\\lt 15.4, W3\\lt 11.6,} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\delta W1\\lt 0.25,\\ \\delta W2\\lt 0.3,\\ \\delta W3\\lt 0.35,}\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{W2-W3\\lt \\mathrm{max}[2.7;\\, 3.15+1.5(W1-W2-1.075)].}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>A cross-match with Gaia yielded 107\u00a0076 sources, of which 2656 are unique multiplets (i.e. WISE sources corresponding to more than one non-duplicate Gaia detection within 6 arcsec from the corresponding WISE position). A significant subset of these (\u22482000) lie within the DES-Y3 footprint. This target list was narrowed down to a sample of 53 candidates by simple visual inspection of their DES images. Among these are some recently discovered lenses, which had been previously identified with other techniques (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The WFI2033-4723 quad (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) was identified as well, whereas WFI2026-4536 was excluded by the WISE colour preselection. In order to prioritize follow-up, candidates can be further graded based on how closely they resemble lenses, based mostly on two criteria: (<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) the presence of two or more blue, compact sources with consistent colours across multiple bands; and (<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) the presence of a (typically red) galaxy between the putative quasar images. Acceptable \u2018new\u2019 candidates identified within this search are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</div>                        <a id=\"118933398\" scrollto-destination=\"118933398\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=jN0UYBFk-IDu2uiEvv8~mk9VgkYj5Xb0USm2FdZexf8YiEVibzctzDym1yU26BRYU7TH-WpB58HtSlQPEuTqQCaU1f-PefxtO3PirV5ZwaL4lTLyq-B~kCU50QIcKTzSTSz0lQidcybOPsDTlnjDSeCsPuN5~3vMQ3FR1jMj4LUmIjOcOFdJfRp4xwHZ89hqcpzpmburvGDjGtVodpfpcsVQc~G7hBzz5OgBc0jwHNcyLseuHeBRRyamlnrCyUZif5767kLXdP6WulUsQJ03rw6kdBSuGieI--FflYt9g3~x1eVZfKU0z4dfX-3O~gMIkD-gwPhvk~wA28pEoiVRyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES single-epoch cutouts of high-grade, multiplet-selected candidates that are not already known lenses. id=\"fn-tb1fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Asterisks mark \u2018new\u2019 lenses in this paper. The i \u2212band (wavg_mag_auto) magnitude refers to the primary DES match of each WISE-detected object, which is often a blend of multiple components.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The same search over the ATLAS-DR3 footprint has yielded candidates that also lie in the DES footprint.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn3\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The last two candidates have been identified among DES multiplets that correspond to Gaia singlets.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Source redshifts are given for systems in this paper that have been confirmed spectroscopically as lenses or near-identical quasar pairs, after this paper was submitted, as part of the STRIDES 2017
