*</sup>\u00a0</td><td>27.736\u00a0921\u00a0</td><td>\u221240.695\u00a0568\u00a0</td><td>18.66\u00a0</td><td>1.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WGD0245-0556<sup><em>b</em>, *</sup>\u00a0</td><td>41.356\u00a0506\u00a0</td><td>\u22125.950\u00a0145\u00a0</td><td>18.73\u00a0</td><td>1.54\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tb1fn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Asterisks mark \u2018new\u2019 lenses in this paper. The i \u2212band (wavg_mag_auto) magnitude refers to the primary DES match of each WISE-detected object, which is often a blend of multiple components.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>The same search over the ATLAS-DR3 footprint has yielded candidates that also lie in the DES footprint.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn3\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The last two candidates have been identified among DES multiplets that correspond to Gaia singlets.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) excludes WGD2047-48 as a line-of-sight alignment of a narrow-line galaxy at <em>z</em> = 0.33, with a red galaxy and a blue star.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tb1fn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tb1fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Some of the WISE\u2013Gaia candidates had also been identified independently, with other techniques, in the STRIDES-2016 campaign (Anguita et al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Treu et al.; in preparation). Source redshifts are given for systems in this paper that have been confirmed spectroscopically as lenses or near-identical quasar pairs, after this paper was submitted, as part of the STRIDES 2017 campaigns.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933399\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some veritable multiplets may have been classified as duplicates in the Gaia-DR1, and so were not flagged by this search. A complementary search, using DES multiplets instead of Gaia-DR1, is outlined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>. It recognized some WISE\u2013Gaia multiplets, and gave at least two additional candidates (WGD0150 and WGD0245, Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, later confirmed as lenses) as WISE\u2013DES multiplets that would correspond to WISE\u2013Gaia singlets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While other lens candidates would require spectroscopic follow-up for confirmation, WGD2038-4008 stood out due to its distinctive configuration, with four blue point-source images around a luminous red galaxy. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows multiband wide-field cutouts of the system and a close-up, with our adopted naming convention for different components and nearby sources.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933402 id=\"118933402\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Spectroscopic confirmation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Both WGD2038-4008 and WGD2021-4115 were observed with long-slit spectroscopy, to secure their lens and source redshifts, as part of a campaign to obtain follow-up spectroscopy of the lens galaxy in various quasar lenses. To this aim, IMACS at the 6.5-m Walter Baade Telescope at Magellan (Las Campanas) was used, set up in \u2018long\u2019 f/4 camera mode, covering the full 4000\u201312\u00a0000-\u00c5 wavelength range. For WGD 2038-4008, the slit was simply oriented north\u2013south and centred on the lens galaxy; since WGD2021-4115 required proper spectroscopic confirmation, the slit was oriented along the two blue images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows the extracted spectra of both systems. From emission lines, the source redshifts of the quad and double are <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 0.777 \u00b1 0.001 and <em>z<sub>s</sub></em> = 1.390 \u00b1 0.001, respectively. Absorption features, compatible with <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.230 \u00b1 0.002 on the quad and <em>z<sub>l</sub></em> = 0.335 \u00b1 0.002 on the double, are also identified.</p>                        <a id=\"118933405\" scrollto-destination=\"118933405\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" best-fit SIE models (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), with arrival-time contours (dashed) and images of circular source-plane isophotes (full lines), for WGD2038-4008 (<em>top</em>) and WGD2021-4115 (<em>bottom</em>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the high-grade candidates from this search, along with source redshifts obtained in subsequent STRIDES-2017 campaigns. Eight systems (marked by asterisks in the table) are confirmed lenses. Of these, WGD0508-2748 has \u22480.8 arcsec image separation and could be confirmed only through high-resolution imaging follow-up, which enabled the identification of the (faint) lens galaxy (Molina et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933408 id=\"118933408\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 CUTOUT MODELS AND LENS PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Simple lens properties can be obtained by modelling the DES image cutouts. In particular, from the <em>grizY</em> survey images, we obtained photometry and relative astrometry of multiple components in the two confirmed lenses, and simple lens models based on those. Lens model configurations are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933410 id=\"118933410\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 WGD2038-4008: system configuration and gravitational lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WGD2038-4008 has a quite symmetric configuration: two saddle-point images aligned along the major axis of the deflector, and the two minima on a nearly perpendicular line. These components are all blended together by the DES pipeline, but can be disentangled by modelling the DES cutouts as a superposition of four point sources and a galaxy, for which we choose a single S\u00e9rsic profile (S\u00e9rsic <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1968</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118933412 id=\"118933412\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Photometry and astrometry of WGD2038-4008</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use a nearby, bright point source (indicated as \u2018O\u2019 in Fig. 1) to directly model the point-spread function (PSF) and the slight offset among different bands. In each band, the PSF is well fit (to within 10\u2009per\u2009cent) by a superposition of three concentric Gaussians with the same axis ratios and orientations, contributing 61\u2009, 33\u2009, and 6\u2009per\u2009cent of the total flux in the core, wings, and outskirts, respectively. Residuals from PSF mismatch are due to multipolar features that are not captured by these simple models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> lists the relative positions and <em>grizY</em> magnitudes of the four images (A, B, C, and D), deflector (G) and three additional sources (S1, S2, and S3). The deflector has a compact bulge and an extended and luminous \u2018halo\u2019, which contributes most of the light and is fit by a S\u00e9rsic profile with <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> = (3.45 \u00b1 0.12) arcsec, <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.90 \u00b1 0.05, axis ratio <em>q</em> = 0.77 \u00b1 0.01 and p.a. \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> = (41.6 \u00b1 1.6) deg (E of N). Faint features in blue bands are visible, with isophotes twisting towards 30-deg east of north. Contamination by the deflector affects the position and fluxes of image D, whose uncertainties are systematics-dominated.</p>                        <a id=\"118933415\" scrollto-destination=\"118933415\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions (relative to image A) and magnitudes of the objects in the lenses, from a joint model of the DES <em>grizY</em> single-epoch images with best image quality. The first column also lists the effective radius (<em>R<sub>e</sub></em>) and S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>) of the deflector in each system. For WGD2038-4008, the PSF is fit directly to the bright star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and three nearby compact sources are included in the fit, in order to limit systematic uncertainties on positions and magnitudes. The magnitudes quoted for G are from the main halo component, whose light dominates over the compact bulge (visible in the residuals), which is roughly as bright as image D. Uncertainties on displacements and magnitudes of image D are systematically dominated, due to contamination by G. Magnitudes in square brackets (for source S2) may be significantly affected by noise and contamination by G. For the subsequent doubles (WGD2021-4115 onwards), the PSF is fit to the farthest quasar image. The cutout image quality and proximity of deflector and counterimage render the fitted positions and magnitudes significantly uncertain. WGD0508 (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is not modelled, due to its very small image separation.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933415\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions (relative to image A) and magnitudes of the objects in the lenses, from a joint model of the DES <em>grizY</em> single-epoch images with best image quality. The first column also lists the effective radius (<em>R<sub>e</sub></em>) and S\u00e9rsic index (<em>n</em>) of the deflector in each system. For WGD2038-4008, the PSF is fit directly to the bright star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and three nearby compact sources are included in the fit, in order to limit systematic uncertainties on positions and magnitudes. The magnitudes quoted for G are from the main halo component, whose light dominates over the compact bulge (visible in the residuals), which is roughly as bright as image D. Uncertainties on displacements and magnitudes of image D are systematically dominated, due to contamination by G. Magnitudes in square brackets (for source S2) may be significantly affected by noise and contamination by G. For the subsequent doubles (WGD2021-4115 onwards), the PSF is fit to the farthest quasar image. The cutout image quality and proximity of deflector and counterimage render the fitted positions and magnitudes significantly uncertain. WGD0508 (see Table<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is not modelled, due to its very small image separation.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933415\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118933416 id=\"118933416\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 Properties of the deflector galaxy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From the magnitudes of G as measured from the cutouts, we can infer its stellar mass. To this aim, we use the <span class=\"small-caps\">Fast</span> code (Kriek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), with an exponentially declining star-formation history and a Salpeter stellar IMF. We adopt the nominal magnitude uncertainties (\u03b4m = 0.016) from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, obtaining <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}(M_{\\star }/M_{\\odot })=11.40^{+0.01}_{-0.08}.$|</span> The highly skewed confidence intervals for <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> are a consequence of the small (statistical) uncertainties on the measured magnitudes and, consequently, of the steepness of the 4000-\u00c5 break. With current, broad-band data, different stellar templates are indistinguishable.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Simple lens models can be fit using the measured image positions as constraints. We do not consider flux ratio constraints, as they can be easily affected by differential reddening, microlensing, and time delays (e.g. Yonehara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>). We adopt a singular isothermal ellipsoid for the deflector, with deflections <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update215118_update215118_equ2\" content-id=\"update215118_update215118_equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\alpha _{X}\\ =\\ -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} \\arctan \\left(\\frac{X\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{\\sqrt{q^{2}X^{2}+Y^{2}}}\\right)\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\alpha _{Y}\\ =\\ -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} {\\rm arctanh} \\left(\\frac{Y\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{\\sqrt{q^{2}X^{2}+Y^{2}}}\\right)\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>in a system aligned along the principal axes (<em>X, Y</em>) of G. Here, the deflector is described solely by its lens strength <em>b</em> and axis ratio <em>q</em>, besides its position angle \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub>. We add an external shear component with uniform prior on the amplitude within 0.0 &lt; <em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em> &lt; 0.14 and uniform prior of the shear angle 0.0 &lt; \u03d5<sub><em>s</em></sub> &lt; \u03c0, and explore three different choices for the deflector shape parameters: (a) priors on <em>q</em> and \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> centred on those from cutout modelling, with larger adopted uncertainties of 0.1 and 10\u00a0deg, respectively; (b) \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> fixed to its value from cutout models, and <em>q</em> free to vary; and (c) uniform priors on <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub>. In all models, the Einstein radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm E}=b/\\sqrt{q}$|</span> has a uniform prior between 1.0 and 3.0 arcsec.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the lens model results. The Einstein radius is quite robust against the adopted priors, and approximately half the A-B image separation. The lens position angle is always close to those observed from the cutouts, whereas a significant shear-ellipticity degeneracy is present. More accurate lens models should account for the variation in shape and position angle of the observed isophotes (e.g. by using a superposition of ellipsoidal models), and possibly incorporate observations of galaxies in the vicinity of the lens in projection, to independently assess the shear component.</p>                        <a id=\"118933420\" scrollto-destination=\"118933420\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens model parameters: Einstein radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm E}=b/\\sqrt{q},$|</span> axis ratio <em>q</em>, and p.a. \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> of the main lens; external shear angle \u03d5<sub><em>s</em></sub> and amplitude \u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>; and lens centre (\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em>, \u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em>) with respect to the galaxy centre identified in the DES cutouts. Image positions are fit with an SIE for the deflector (G) and external shear to account for possible external contributions. Different lines correspond to different priors adopted on the shape parameters <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> of G (see text).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Mod.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<em><sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg. E of N)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg. N of W)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>J2038-4008\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (a)\u00a0</td><td>1.26 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.79 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>42.0 \u00b1 7.7\u00a0</td><td>25.0 \u00b1 7.0\u00a0</td><td>0.095 \u00b1 0.025\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.04 \u00b1 0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.04 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (b)\u00a0</td><td>1.26 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.64 \u00b1 0.22\u00a0</td><td>42.0 \u00b1 7.0\u00a0</td><td>18.0 \u00b1 35.0\u00a0</td><td>0.07 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.06 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.05 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mod. Image positions are fit with an SIE for the deflector (G) and external shear to account for possible external contributions. Different lines correspond to different priors adopted on the shape parameters <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> of G (see text).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Mod.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<em><sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>x<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>y<sub>G</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(deg. (a)\u00a0</td><td>1.25 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.50 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td><td>8.0 \u00b1 4.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>0.02 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.00 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Mod. (b)\u00a0</td><td>1.06 \u00b1 0.07\u00a0</td><td>[1.0]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>-11.0\u00b15.0\u00a0</td><td>0.21 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.03 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.02 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118933420\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933421 id=\"118933421\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 WGD2021-4115: system configuration and gravitational lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WGD2021-4115 consists of two quasar images at either side of a round, faint, red galaxy (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We denote the farther image (with shorter arrival time) as A. Its counterimage B lies very close to the deflector galaxy. The same approach as above has been followed for WGD2021-4115, obtaining object positions and <em>grizY</em> magnitudes from the DES image cutouts and performing simple lens models. The astrometry and photometry of the three components is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. In this case, G is smaller, fainter, and very close to image B, which makes the cutout models highly degenerate. The structural parameters of G cannot be recovered reliably, and its magnitudes have significant uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From simple lens models, a high-quadrupole component (shear <em>\u03b3<sub>s</sub></em> = 0.20 \u00b1 0.04 or flattening <em>q</em> = 0.50 \u00b1 0.08) is needed to account for the off-centring of images A and B with respect to the lens galaxy, still producing only two quasar images due to the highly asymmetric configuration. The Einstein radius ((1.25 \u00b1 0.05) arcsec from SIE, (1.06 \u00b1 0.07) arcsec from SIS + XS) is comparable to half the A\u2013B image separation, but due to the significant quadrupole it depends appreciably on the chosen lens model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similar arguments hold in general for the remaining doubles in this sample. With current imaging data, the lens parameters have comparable uncertainties for all doubles. Lens models based on follow-up, adaptive-optics assisted imaging are beyond the scope of this paper, and will be presented elsewhere (Molina et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933425 id=\"118933425\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The combination of WISE colour selection and Gaia/DES image quality and depth has resulted in the discovery of the lensed quasar quad WGD2038-4008 and a sample of high-grade candidate doubles, seven of which have been confirmed as lenses (Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Due to different survey strategy, source-detection pipelines, and depth and image quality, Gaia can detect multiple sources that are unrecognized in DES and vice versa. Also, the current performance of the WISE\u2013Gaia multiplet search is limited by the preselection cuts in WISE and absence of colour information in Gaia-DR1. These aspects are discussed below.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933427 id=\"118933427\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 DES multiplets</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The WISE\u2013Gaia search took 173\u00a0048 input positions, but resulted in fewer (107\u00a0076) output detections. This is mostly because of the current Gaia-DR1 <span class=\"monospace\">source</span> completeness towards faint magnitudes, and pipeline-specific choices in source detection and deblending. By contrast, a WISE\u2013DES match resulted in 206\u00a0671 entries, meaning that \u224850 \u00d7 10<sup>3</sup> WISE objects correspond to multiple DES-detected sources within a search radius of 10 arcsec. This suggests that some interesting objects are missed or misclassified by Gaia but can be recovered within DES multiplets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the other hand, many WISE\u2013DES multiplets can contain very faint objects, mostly galaxies, or line-of-sight alignments of extragalactic objects with foreground stars. Foreground star contamination is already present in the WISE\u2013Gaia selection, as the distribution of multiplets is more abundant towards the Galactic disc, the Large Magellanic Cloud and in general along stellar overdensities. In a WISE\u2013DES multiplet search, <em>grizY</em> magnitudes can be used to infer which multiplets are most likely contaminants, and which ones are more promising, as one can expect a qso+star alignment to show two well-separated objects, possibly with different colours.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A simple search can then exclude multiplets with separation \u22733 arcsec and with at least one point source, or multiplets whose primary has promising quasar colours (<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 0.85) and a colour difference |\u03b4(<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>)| &gt; 0.4 between primary and secondary detected sources. The separation criterion is chosen because, at large Einstein radii, the lens galaxy should be detectable by the DESpipeline.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If this selection is effective, what remains should be almost uniformly distributed over the DES footprint. For a first assessment of the efficiency of this procedure, and account for footprint coverage, one can simply plot the distribution of different systems. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the distribution of WISE\u2013DES singlets, WISE\u2013DES multiplets that survive the above cuts in separation and colour difference, and WISE\u2013DES multiplets that should be mostly extragalactic+star alignments. Three distributions are shown, corresponding to singlets/multiplets, whose primary has 23.0 &gt; <em>i</em> &gt; 21.75, 21.75 &gt; <em>i</em> &gt; 20.5, and 20.5 &gt; <em>i</em> respectively. The magnitude separation is used to understand whether contamination is more significant towards faint objects, or in specific regions of the sky.</p>                        <a id=\"118933432\" scrollto-destination=\"118933432\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=dFYtXLimxNMEDbf~aRYz~eo6v6y7Rpx~jB5s0gM~MN~kLGruEsKi1NQjEvQNtkzPuRD8xamG664ldttdyUq2BDkEA5bWrPvnbi7TdJezIFEPfwC4hhtk9wQ9bnsPV5dLpiYmt6ZlDLukwwWsvNV1~ifOfJUk5stPL59EGVqANe3iueD~4X0YugnkiSinhJLIKtJIw~WIBGwRCkebpfZu6xi4oFiyXMRBM66Gcs3r~31lkcnzeR88UWIMSa-FHSt6lI4bO--mAE5w8jewNT8l189x6kZ5t0ACsEusu44HW3klmBvZ30LrjLuMD7LdHcbKoihi4-nK9gBm31ZAtSnD-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has i &lt; 20.5 (wavg_mag_auto); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933432/sty1419fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933432\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=UjsTBqVgtIH7hghdPERbv69-Q5DYCCxAGx7DBXUEza-TfSdbXUkXcf9W7yCENsW9g13TQZR3jw8RqhjC7M1AEYI4CSk6UgviUImBdF5DTb7GWDZdc9eHYk4Jp6F66KqXFi2e3C1sh2QWxN~oHppCojJzrhU5h1JnaUDoVO9R5o36CZB0sBjupHz7k9~WW0DPt5TSCCsDYe~GtChVXDr1OFfSpQuCRX3zszQS625M6Htqv53HagWgQe7QR2WpQIHGeMG~i1X0Ko2Mb8A4IX8Qd1ir~5BWk0Q9xtDZw~savgdB~gH4XPfRJFkM2GLSdKwg71-EJx~sWtZDBgObN9k8Xw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933432&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (<span class=\"monospace\">wavg_mag_auto</span>); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/m_sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&amp;Signature=dFYtXLimxNMEDbf~aRYz~eo6v6y7Rpx~jB5s0gM~MN~kLGruEsKi1NQjEvQNtkzPuRD8xamG664ldttdyUq2BDkEA5bWrPvnbi7TdJezIFEPfwC4hhtk9wQ9bnsPV5dLpiYmt6ZlDLukwwWsvNV1~ifOfJUk5stPL59EGVqANe3iueD~4X0YugnkiSinhJLIKtJIw~WIBGwRCkebpfZu6xi4oFiyXMRBM66Gcs3r~31lkcnzeR88UWIMSa-FHSt6lI4bO--mAE5w8jewNT8l189x6kZ5t0ACsEusu44HW3klmBvZ30LrjLuMD7LdHcbKoihi4-nK9gBm31ZAtSnD-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has i &lt; 20.5 (wavg_mag_auto); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118933432/sty1419fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118933432\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1419/1/sty1419fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465836&Signature=UjsTBqVgtIH7hghdPERbv69-Q5DYCCxAGx7DBXUEza-TfSdbXUkXcf9W7yCENsW9g13TQZR3jw8RqhjC7M1AEYI4CSk6UgviUImBdF5DTb7GWDZdc9eHYk4Jp6F66KqXFi2e3C1sh2QWxN~oHppCojJzrhU5h1JnaUDoVO9R5o36CZB0sBjupHz7k9~WW0DPt5TSCCsDYe~GtChVXDr1OFfSpQuCRX3zszQS625M6Htqv53HagWgQe7QR2WpQIHGeMG~i1X0Ko2Mb8A4IX8Qd1ir~5BWk0Q9xtDZw~savgdB~gH4XPfRJFkM2GLSdKwg71-EJx~sWtZDBgObN9k8Xw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118933432&ar=5032807&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1419fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">WISE\u2013DES singlets and multiplets. Each row of density maps corresponds to a different macroclass: WISE sources corresponding to DES singlets; WISE sources corresponding to (possibly) extragalactic multiplets; and WISE sources corresponding to multiplets that likely contain a foreground star. In the second line, blue points mark WISE\u2013DES multiplets whose primary has <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (<span class=\"monospace\">wavg_mag_auto</span>); in the third line, the blue points are the 2656 WISE\u2013Gaia target multiplets. Axes intercept at the location of the Globular Cluster NGC 1851.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We remark that, within the search reported in this paper, these plots have mostly an illustrative purpose. A ranking based on local (over-)density was not used, since the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {O}(10^3)$|</span> targets could be quickly inspected visually, but has been developed in subsequent work on larger footprints and looser colour preselection.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fourth column displays the multiplet distribution regardless of primary magnitude. The blue points in the last row show the distribution of all WISE\u2013Gaia multiplet targets from Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Among the WISE\u2013DES multiplets with acceptable configurations and colour differences, many have extended morphology,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> a secondary with <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &gt; 1, and small colour differences (|\u03b4(<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>)| &lt; 0.2, |\u03b4(<em>r</em> \u2212 <em>z</em>)| &lt; 0.2). They can be interpreted as pairs of compact narrow-line galaxies, a common contaminant in quasar lens searches without <em>u</em> \u2212band information. A na\u00efve selection may then require <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 0.85 for all sources. The resulting multiplets with primary <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 are shown by blue dots in the second row of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, and amount to 233 (respectively 179, 405) pairs with secondary <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (respectively 20.5 &lt; <em>i</em> &lt; 21.75, 21.75 &lt; <em>i</em> &lt; 23.0). These have been visually inspected, finding some WISE\u2013Gaia candidates independently and yielding at least two good candidates that corresponded to Gaia-DR1 singlets (see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), WGD0150 and WGD025, subsequently confirmed spectroscopically as lenses.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118933435 id=\"118933435\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Future prospects</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This search has mostly relied on a WISE\u2013Gaia preselection, with a final step of DES image inspection. The WISE colour preselection, tailored on the majority of known lenses, may nonetheless be too restrictive, as it discards some known lenses (including quads) in the remaining \u2018upper wedge\u2019 <em>W</em>2 \u2212 <em>W</em>3 &gt;\u20093.15 + 1.5(<em>W</em>1 \u2212 <em>W</em>2 \u2212 1.075). A crude estimate, based on the number of known lenses that lie in the excluded region, suggests that a further \u224850\u2009per\u2009cent of targets (and possibly candidates) can be identified there.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While quads like WGD2038-4008 need little follow-up for confirmation, spatially resolved spectroscopy of candidate doubles is necessary. A clear example is given by WGD2047-4814 (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>): it had already been selected with a different technique (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>) in DES-Y2 and prioritized as a high-grade candidate, but it was recognized by long-slit spectroscopy (SOAR-Goodman, PI V. Motta) as a <em>z</em> = 0.33 narrow-line galaxy aligned with a red galaxy and a blue star (Motta, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, private communication).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A key component of this investigation was the detection of Gaia multiplets, not flagged as duplicate detections, within a 6 arcsec search radius from WISE-selected quasars. Given the Gaia scanning strategy and object-detection pipeline, some actual multiplets may have been flagged as duplicates in the Gaia-DR1 catalogue. In fact, only about\u200920\u221230\u2009per\u2009cent of known lenses are currently recognized as multiple unique sources in Gaia-DR1. Upcoming releases (aiming at 0.4 arcsec resolution) may alleviate this issue, since each object is visited multiple times and with different orientations. A complementary search, examining WISE\u2013DES multiplets, may refine the distance/colour cuts explored above (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>), adopting a population-mixture approach for pairs/multiplets of objects. This may, in fact, be possible already at the level of Gaia colours, as Gaia-DR2 is also providing \u2018blue\u2019 and \u2018red\u2019 internal magnitudes.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933439 id=\"118933439\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the first results of a new search for lensed quasars based on the combination of mid-infrared photometry from WISE, high resolution from Gaia, and multiband optical imaging from DES. This search has found already-known lenses and some new ones discovered during the STRIDES-2016/2017 campaigns,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> and it yielded \u224850 quasar lens candidates in the DES-Y3 footprint, of which 18 high-grade candidates are presented in this paper (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of these, WGD2038-4008 is a quadruply lensed quasar, not previously found with other techniques. Its deflector is a massive (log\u2009(<em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>) \u2248 11.5) and low-redshift (<em>z<sub>l</sub></em> \u2248 0.23) luminous red galaxy, with a compact bulge, a bright halo contributing most of the light, and indication of isophotal shape variations at large distances. Simple lens models can be well fit to its image configuration. The deflector shape parameters obtained from lensing are in general agreement with those observed from the DES <em>grizY</em> cutouts, but there are significant quadrupole degeneracies that will need follow-up imaging to be resolved. The Einstein radius is quite robustly constrained at (1.30 \u00b1 0.04) arcsec, whereas the main \u2018halo\u2019 component of the deflector has half-light radius <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> = (3.45 \u00b1 0.12) arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The double WGD2021-4115 has been followed up spectroscopically and confirmed as a lens. Its configuration has an arrival-time minimum (image A) well separated from the blend of arrival-time saddle point (image B) and deflector. A high-quadrupole component is expected from our first lens models, and the Einstein radius (1.3 arcsec &gt; \u03b8<sub>E</sub> &gt; 1.0 arcsec) can vary appreciably because of this.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The WISE\u2013Gaia\u2013DES multiplet search can be further developed in multiple ways. Multiband information from DES can be used to augment the multiplet recognition, by pruning different classes of contaminants. The WISE colour preselection can be performed with looser cuts, or within a population-mixture classification to exclude the most abundant contaminant classes. Furthermore, chromatic information will be available since Gaia-DR2, and spectra of most Gaia sources will be available upon completion (2020). In fact, archival fibre spectra of WGD2038-4008 were already available from the Six-degree-field Galaxy Survey (6dFGS; Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), where the object was targeted as a bright galaxy and the image quality of older imaging surveys precluded its identification as a lensed quasar.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With this work, we have demonstrated the effectiveness of the WISE\u2013Gaia lens search, discovering new lenses (among which a quadruple), that could not be found with previously developed techniques. At this stage, however, the quantification of how different search techniques are complementary is premature, as comprehensive samples with spectroscopic follow-up are needed to that purpose. Our results suggest that a significant population of lensed quasars may still be found in current surveys, enabling the collection of lens samples for studies of distant quasars (both their hosts and central engines), luminous and dark matter in galaxies over a range of redshifts, and cosmography.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118933445 id=\"118933445\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper was written as part of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) collaboration, a broad external collaboration of the Dark Energy Survey, <span class=\"monospace\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://strides.astro.ucla.edu\" target=\"_blank\">http://strides.astro.ucla.edu</a></span></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">TT acknowledges support from NSF through grant AST-1450141, and from the Packard Foundation through a Packard Research Fellowship. CDF acknowledges support from the U.S. National Science Foundation through grant number AST-1312329.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the DOE and NSF (USA), MISE (Spain), STFC (UK), HEFCE (UK), NCSA (UIUC), KICP (U. Chicago), CCAPP (Ohio State), MIFPA (Texas A&amp;M), CNPQ, FAPERJ, FINEP (Brazil), MINECO (Spain), DFG (Germany), and the Collaborating Institutions in the Dark Energy Survey. The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne Lab, UC Santa Cruz, University of Cambridge, CIEMAT-Madrid, University of Chicago, University College London, DES-Brazil Consortium, University of Edinburgh, ETH Z\u00fcrich, Fermilab, University of Illinois, ICE (IEEC-CSIC), IFAE Barcelona, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, LMU M\u00fcnchen and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, University of Michigan, NOAO, University of Nottingham, Ohio State University, University of Pennsylvania, University of Portsmouth, SLAC National Lab, Stanford University, University of Sussex, and Texas A&amp;M University. Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the Gaia Multilateral Agreement.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work is based in Rep\u00fablica Federativa do Brasil, the U.S. National Optical Astronomy Observatory (NOAO), the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), and Michigan State University (MSU).</p><p from the WISE catalogue.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Wright</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">E. L.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">140</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1868</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib46\" data-legacy-id=\"bib46\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib46\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib46\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib46\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Yonehara</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Mineshige</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Fukue</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Umemura</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Turner</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">E. L.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">1999</div>, <div class=\"source \">AA</div>, <div class=\"volume\">343</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">41</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\">\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n                    <h2 class=\"authorNotes-section-title\" id=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\" scrollto-destination=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\">Author notes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"afn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Packard Fellow. This paper includes data gathered with the 6.5-m Magellan Telescopes located at Las Campanas Observatory, Chile.</p></div></span></div><div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2018 The For a first assessment of the efficiency of this procedure, and account for footprint coverage, one can simply plot the distribution of different systems. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the distribution of WISE\u2013DES singlets, WISE\u2013DES multiplets that survive the above cuts in separation and colour difference, and WISE\u2013DES multiplets that should be mostly extragalactic+star alignments. Jos\u00e9 Cristino 77, Rio de Janeiro, RJ 20921-400, Brazil; Instituto de F\u00edsica Gleb Wataghin, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, 13083-859, Campinas, SP, Brazil), CP(Computer Science and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, USA), CQ(National Center for Supercomputing Applications, 1205 West Clark St., Urbana, IL 61801, USA), CR(Department of Physics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA), CS(Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL 60510, USA), CT(Department of Physics, Stanford University, 382 Via Pueblo Mall, Stanford, CA 94305, USA)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "479", "publication_year": "2018/10/1", "start_page": "4345", "end_page": "4354", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: statistical", "techniques: image processing", "surveys", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.479.4345A", "abstract": "We report the discovery, spectroscopic confirmation, and first lens models of the first, strongly lensed quasars from a combined search in WISE and Gaia-DR1 over the DES footprint. Their Einstein radii span a range between \u22482.0 arcsec and \u22480.4 arcsec. Two of these (WGD2038-4008, RA = 20:38:02.65, Dec. = -40:08:14.64; WGD2021-4115, RA = 20:21:39.45, Dec. = -41:15:57.11) also have confirmed deflector redshifts. The four-image lens WGD2038-4008, with source and deflector redshifts <SUB>s</SUB> = 0.777 \u00b1 0.001 and z<SUB>l</SUB> = 0.230 \u00b1 0.002, respectively, has a deflector with radius R<SUB>eff</SUB> \u2248 3.4 arcsec, stellar mass log (M_{\u22c6}/M_{\u2609})=11.64^{+0.20}_{-0.43}, and extended isophotal shape variation. Simple lens models yield Einstein radii R<SUB>E</SUB> = (1.30 \u00b1 0.04) arcsec, axis ratio q = 0.75 \u00b1 0.1 (compatible with that of the starlight) and considerable shear-ellipticity degeneracies. The two-image lens WGD2021-4115 has z<SUB>s</SUB> = 1.390 \u00b1 0.001 and z<SUB>l</SUB> = 0.335 \u00b1 0.002, and Einstein radius R<SUB>E</SUB> = (1.1 \u00b1 0.1) arcsec, but higher-resolution imaging is needed to accurately separate the deflector and faint quasar image. Analogous lens model degeneracies hold for the other six lenses (J0146-1133, J0150-4041, J0235-2433, J0245-0556, J0259-2338, and J0508-2748) shown in this paper.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/sty1419", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1711.03971", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
